Subjective: Right eye irritation, onset Tuesday AM after waking. Sensation of foreign body, constant. Rubbing eye initially. Redness, increased vascularity noted. Right eye thicker than left. No trauma, no new products (makeup, cream). No contact lens wear. Squeezing eyes shut causes mild pain. Vision normal. No photophobia. No other systemic symptoms (flu). Daughter (Isa) well. Boyfriend on holiday. Request: Wants to know if eye drops or antibiotics needed. Fear of contagion.
Objective: Right eye: Redness, increased vascularity. Left eye: Developing redness. Pupils reactive to light bilaterally. No foreign body seen on external exam or under eyelids. No discharge noted.
Assessment: Viral conjunctivitis, bilateral. Right eye initially affected, left eye now developing. No evidence of bacterial superinfection or foreign body.
Plan:
1. Reassurance: Viral conjunctivitis is self-limiting.
2. Artificial tears: Use as needed for comfort (e.g., Kruidvat brand).
3. Hygiene: Lukewarm tap water for cleaning stuck eyelids in AM.
4. Avoid rubbing eye.
5. Safety netting: Return if increased pain, purulent discharge, eyelids stuck shut, or visual changes.
6. Follow-up: Return in 2 weeks if symptoms persist.
